لتاريخ قبل سنة 1552

منقول بدون تغيير من صفحة تحمل الرابط التالي:

http://www.1000kzn.ru/razdel/en/227/

During 115 years - lifetime of the Kazan Khanate, the rulers changes 14 times, though all in all there were 21 periods of reign. It happened so, because some khans occupied the throne for 2-3 times. Muhammad-Amin took the pledge not to struggle against Russia and to protect the interests of Russian people living in the Khanate. The citizens of Kazan had no right to choose a new khan without the permission of the Great Khan. Lots of Kazan grandees were dissatisfied with the situation, when Kazan depended on Moscow. In 1496 not without the help of conspirators the throne occupied Siberian khan Mamuk, but in a year he was “dismissed as incompetent” – he was no good as a governor, besides he abused his power and squandered public funds. With the consent of Ivan III, the throne occupied Abdul-Latif who was brought up in the Crimea. But as the time passed this khan began to follow anti-Muscovy politics; and in 1502 Ivan III gave order to exile him to the north of Russia

Muhammad-Amin came to power for the second time. He didn’t want to be banished from Kazan again and thus he started a real war with Muscovy. In June 1505 people of Kazan attacked the envoy of the Great Prince and Russian merchants. Muhammad-Amin with his army set out against Moscow, besieged Nizhny Novgorod, and up to 1507 the general course of action was in his favour. Finally Muhammad-Amin signed a peace treaty with Vasily III “out of friendship”. 10 years of truce allowed Kazan to achieve great results in its development

After Muhammad-Amin died in 1518 his throne passed to Shah-Ali, but the latter very soon was deposed. He was replaced by Sakhib-Girey, the son of Crimean khan

He began his reign with extermination of Russian merchants living in Kazan and the envoy of the Great Prince; after that he moved with his army to Moscow and besieged it. Vasily III had to sign a treaty on terms of levy payment “according to regulations of ancient times”. 3 years later the throne passed to Sakhib-Girey’s nephew – Safa-Girey

Safa-Girey 3 times organized campaigns against Muscovy; Ivan the Terrible in his turn 3 times sent his army to Kazan. Safa-Girey twice was dethroned, still each time he would return with the help of Nogaisky and Crimean armies. People of Kazan strongly disliked the way Safa-Girey reined, though they didn’t like provisional government of Muscovy protégés Dzhan-Ali and Shah-Ali either (by the way, the latter remained at the throne for about a month only)

In 1551 Ivan IV started preparations for decisive march against Kazan and gradually occupied adjoining territories. At the place where Sviyaga flows into Volga there was built a fortress Sviyazhsk; Crimean garrison left Kazan. A part of Kazan grandees decided to appease Ivan IV, thus they removed from the throne the regent Sujumbike – mother of Safa-Girey’s infant son Utyamish-Girey. Shah-Ali came to the throne again. Still Ivan IV didn’t give back the captured territories and it was clear he was going to put an end to the Kazan Khanate. In 1552 Shah-Ali left the throne and conveyed to Sviyazhsk large fortress cannons, harquebuses; also he spoiled the gun powder. People of Kazan invited to the throne the Prince of Astrakhan Yadigar

At the end of August, 1552 a huge army headed by Ivan IV reached Kazan. This army consisted of 60 thousand of foot and cavalry, including tatar horsemen of Shah-Ali. It was twice as much as the army of Kazan

Fierce battles lasted for about a month. The “Kazan history” says: “It was terrifying to see the bravery and courage of both armies: one side wanted to enter the city, the other won’t let them do it”

The Russian army used cannons that fired from high movable towers. The cannon-balls ruined the inner part of the city. The horsemen of Yapancha, troops of Mari and Chuvash people were defeated. A spring was destroyed by explosion and the deposited were left without water.

Early in the morning on September, 2, the wall of the Kazan Kremlin was exploded – mine-layers of Ivan IV piled there tens of powder-barrels. The tsar’s army rushed into the breaches. Kazan people struggled doughtily: they threw from the walls huge logs, poured burning oil; thousands of arrows covered the sky. Shakirds headed by seid Kul Sharif were fighting like mad. But the forces were unequal

Yadigar gave himself up. A small part of defenders managed to run Russian blockade.

The city was totally defeated. Its citizens were either killed or captured. Feudal lords of Kazan lost their power. Garrisons of Muscovy occupied main towns of the land

The downfall of Kazan didn’t mean that people of Kazan stopped their resistance. During several next years they tried without success to restore the Kazan Khanate

1801 – starting of regional printing shop in Kazan.

1803 – P. Esipov built the city theatre.

1804 17 November – opening of Kazan Emperor University.

1804 17 November – the first literary evening was carried out at Fuks’ house.

1805 21 March – a military school opened up in Kazan.

1806 23 April – the first meeting of the Russian philology enthusiasts club.

1809 1 March – a special military hospital for 300 patients was opened.

1811 19 April – first issue of Kazan periodic press progenitor - “Kazanskiye Vedomosti”

came out.

1815-1820 – I. L. Tolstoy, Leo Tolstoy’s grandfather was Kazan’s mayor.

1821 – magazine of “Kazanskiy vestnik” began to come out.

1832 – first copy of “Zavolzhskiy muravei” magazine appeared.

1833 5-8 September – A. S. Pushkin’s staying in Kazan.

1834 – “Sceintific transactions of Kazan University” first publishing.

1837 – Kazan was visited by V. A. Zhukovskiy.

1838 1 January – first number of “Kazanskiye gubernskiye vedomosti” was issued.

1839 – establishing of Kazan Economic society.

1841 – opening of Kazan Rodion Ladies Institute.

1841 – from that year on Leo Tolstoy began his studying in Kazan.

1844 3 January – N. K. Bazhenov came to Kazan to take up a staff doctor vacancy at

the powder works and wrote in the aftermath his three-volume work on “Kazan History”.

1844 11 January – first orphan asylum opened up in Kazan.

1845 6 May – construction of the building for the Assembly of the Nobility began.

1845 8 May – construction of the building for the Kazan seminary began (at the present

known as 6th municipal hospital).

1848 2 January – opening of the city public bank.

1850 24 May – opening of the ladies’ school (later known as the ladies’ gymnasium).

1851 – setting up of iron foundry of Sveshnikov.

1855 – opening of candle works and soap factory of Krestnikov brothers.

1859 18 December – first Kazan telegraph station came into action.

1860 – setting up of cotton mill, weaving mill and tannery of Alafuzov brothers.

1860 13 November – a ladies’ Sunday school opens under the Kazan Emperor

University.

1864 – establishing of the Kazan military district.

1865 10 January – opening of city public library.

1866 – Kazan post office was established.

1866 11 November – Kazan exchange was opened.

1868 9 February – G. Derzhavin’s monument was moved from the Kazan Emperor

University’s yard to the Theatre square (Freedom square, the place of the Opera

House).

1868 – organizing of the Kazan doctors’ society.

1870 19 December – for the first time in Kazan a case was heard in the court

participated by the jury.

1870 16 June – the “City Statute” with regulation on the order of the municipal

government was published.

1870 – first elections to the town council.

1871 6 January – first annually calendar in Tatar is published by K. Nasyri.

1872 3 January – publication of “Volzhsko-Kamskaya gazeta” began.

1872 21 September – opening of the seminary for non-Russian teachers (Tatar national

teachers seminary).

1873 – establishing of the Kazan water supply society.

1874 – veterinary Institute was opened.

1874 – opening of the urban water supply.

1874 19 December – first gas lanterns appeared in the streets and squares of Kazan.

1875 2 October – starting of the horse-drawn tram.

1876 3 October – beginning of the Ladies high course.

1876 24 October – opening of the teachers Institute.

1876 – opening of the Tatar teachers’ school.

1881 29 March – a journalist and a writer M. N. Kildibekov (1881-1949) born this day was

among the first organizers of the national press.

1881 – opening of first music school.

1883 – “Volzhskiy vestnik” newspaper began to come out.

1884-1888 – M. Gorkiy’s staying in Kazan.

1887 6 November – “Noble Meeting” opened in Kazan.

1887 16 December – students in the Kazan University had a gathering at which Vladimir

Ulyanov also took part.

1888 27 November – a telephone station for 70 subscribers opened up in Kazan.

1890 11 December – first copy of “Kazanskiye vesti” was issued.

1891 29 April – Moscow-Ryazan railway was renamed as Kazanskaya.

1893 – the train service began on Kazan railway.

1893 – a monument to N. M. Lobachevskiy was erected.

1894 18 March – setting up of Belgian horse-drawn trams joint stock company.

1894 11 June – opening of railway communication between Kazan and Zeleniy Dol

where the first train consisted of four coaches.

1895 5 April – city science and industry museum was opened.

1895 26 April – construction of Bogoyavlenskiy bell tower at Bolshaya Prolomnaya

begins.

1895 9 September – opening of art school (now is art professional school).

1896 29 April – in commemoration of Karl Fuks’ death, public garden at Koziy Bugor

was equipped with the amenities.

1897 15 March – Fyodor Shalyapin’s first performance in Kazan.

1897 10 September – opening of manufacture’s school.

1898 16 April – first filming was carried out in Kazan.

1899 28 January – the book by Karl Fuks “History of Kazan” passed censor for

publication.

1899 20 November – first electricity tram appeared in Kazan.
